I had a break from my training. I was going to do something else. Being a successful Olympian is a special thing. I had the chance to do more writing and TV work, and to speak to businesses and schools. But there wasn’t anything on the horizon to get my competitive teeth into. I knew that I wished to stay in shape, so that I would be in a position to fight for an Olympic place if that dream reignited within me. So I entered marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but there was still the TV presenter Ben Fogle’s nagging invitation at the back of my mind. I was beginning to miss that feeling, but I still wasn’t ready to commit to the regime of training seven days a week. I spoke to some of my rowing colleagues about whether they fancied the race; I didn’t receive any enthusiastic responses. I knew that if I entered the race, even though it is billed primarily as an adventure, I would want to win. I got in contact with Ben. We spoke about the remaining costs of the race. We felt we stood a better chance than most, but it would still take work to secure it. Of course, I also had to take into account the loss of earnings that would result from being away from home. I had to weigh up the pros and cons of doing the race. I decided to do it. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one of the biggest lessons was to be thankful for the easy life of a full-time athlete.

Last year, I went to the Arctic Circle in Finland to work with huskies. I was 26 and I was feeling restless. I found a small company run by Anna and Pasi. They agreed to take me on as a husky dog handler for the winter season.
From December to February, there is a lot of business taking tourists out on sled rides. The company started with six dogs, and it grew to more than 100. Recently, they took over a second property. I could join the team for three months, but I knew the hours would be long and the conditions would be tough.
I arrived at the farm and was handed a pair of boots and turned out into the cold. I followed the sound of barking and joined the team of husky guides. It was a lot of fun, but it was also very difficult. I had to learn how to drive a snowmobile and how to feed and water the dogs. But I was triumphant. I emailed my friends and told them I could chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw in the snow.

On that day, Radcliffe ran very fast and won the race. The press was there to make sense of her extraordinary run. Her time was so good that it would have qualified her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Journalists asked her about the benefits of emu oil, which Olympic gold medallist, Cathy Freeman, had recommended. Radcliffe feels that her achievement never really sank in. She was proud of what she had accomplished and felt that it was what she was meant to do that day. During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio coverage. With 800m left to run, Radcliffe began to calculate. She knew she could finish in under 2 hours 16 minutes if she crossed the line in less than three minutes. She ran quickly and finished the race in 2 hours 16 minutes and 25 seconds. After the race, everyone wanted to know how she had beaten the grace and skill of the East African runners. Her physiotherapist, Gerard Hartmann, had stayed with her for weeks and provided daily sessions to counter the pain she was experiencing. He says that Radcliffe was so strong that he had to go deep into her muscles and ice his thumbs afterwards. During that period, Hartmann gave so much of his time to Radcliffe that his other athletes became resentful.

When I first started a cookery programme called In Search of Perfection, I was not sure how people would react to it. There had been a lot of talk about the food revolution happening in Britain, and I was confident that we had created a series of programmes that made a new contribution to that. But I was still worried about whether people would appreciate an approach to cooking that involved more than just techniques. I watched the first programme and was relieved that it was well-received. The success of the show led to other projects, including a book based on my experiences at the restaurant I own. In each project, there is a sense of adventure, whether it's into the past, into the mind, or into cookery techniques. I wrote several books in a series called 'Perfection', each one accompanying its own TV programme of the same name. In these books, the journey was often physical, with passports and suitcases and itineraries. The latest book in the series is called In Search of Total Perfection. It takes you on a journey around the world to meet extraordinary artisans. Despite the book's title, I knew that I wouldn't be claiming the recipes were perfect. But I thought that, by using my skills and knowledge, I could pin down some of the things that made these dishes work.

We were driving to Marrakech when the van broke down and crashed into a field. John got out and opened the hood of the car. He stood there for a long time looking at the engine. He said, "Actually, I haven't a clue what I'm doing." Mum and I started to laugh. The field was big and there was nothing in it except grass and flowers. We sat on the side of the road and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John walk away. Mum stretched out on the grass. She asked me to tell her a story. I told her about two birds I heard talking. The birds talked about breadcrumbs and other birds. I also told her about the weather and the argument they had over a worm. Bea said, "That's stupid, no-one understands bird language." I felt sad. But my voice didn't sound very convincing. Bea said, "Liar." I was angry. How could I be lying if I remembered every single word? The more I thought about it, the more I wasn't sure. I started to worry about how we would get home. I thought it might be easier if we could take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.

Lucy was talking to two other pianists at the welcome party in the hotel ballroom. They were older than her and spoke good English. They talked about the pieces they were playing, where they had travelled recently, and where they were going next.
Lucy had not wanted to go to the festival, but she had made it. Her dad bought her a necklace and her brother got excited about it. Her teacher took her out for a special dinner to strategize a repertoire.
The festival was important and there was a lot of buzz about Lucy. Everyone knew who she was. She felt like she mattered.

Your dad might be right. Spending too much time online can be unhealthy. But research shows that most teenagers who use social media have a lot of friends, a good sense of identity and belonging, and are developing the skills they need to be successful in the digital age.
There are a few things that social networking can do for you. It can help you develop your self-identity, connect with others who share your interests, and help you be creative. If you're not outgoing, social networking can be a more comfortable way to communicate. If you're a quiet person with a specialized interest, social networking can help you connect with others who share your passion.
Social networking is also becoming a creative force. Teenagers are making videos, podcasting and blogging about the things that interest them. Photo-sharing sites are transforming creativity. Keen photographers can network with each other, learn skills, swap images and deepen their own interest.
So, if you're a teenager, and you're not sure what to do with your time, social networking might be a great way to spend your time. You can use it to connect with friends, learn new skills, and express yourself creatively.

When most people think of a family vacation, I guess a trip through the western states in the US and Canada doesn’t come to mind. However, my parents clearly weren’t looking to put their feet up as they organized our summer vacation this year. My dad seemed to have taken it upon himself to plan the ultimate family bonding trip. We packed a lot of stuff into the car, including suitcases, coolers, and clothing. We set off on our journey and traveled for many miles. We stopped at a town in Oklahoma and learned the rule of the road: cattle get the right-of-way. We also visited the Great Sand Dunes and Pagosa Springs, Colorado. We learned that what are marked as Jeep roads are best left to Jeep drivers. We saw a lot of interesting sights on our trip, including wind farms and bear habitats. We also had a close encounter with a bear. After watching a rainstorm blow through, we made our way back south. It was bittersweet to be home again, but I was glad that I hadn’t fought with my brother.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Her family was separating for two years. Her father had an assignment overseas, and her mother would be joining him, but Rose and her sister Amy were staying in England. Amy was completing her final school courses and would be living under the guardianship of the college Head. It was her last year at school, so it would have been unfair on Amy to move.
Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She had never known her grandfather and had vague holiday memories of her grandmother. Her parents had not been enthused by the idea of her living with her grandmother, but Daisy had insisted that it was no trouble.
Rose was sensible and very mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, about keeping fit, and getting enough sleep. But this time Rose had insisted on one thing: she wanted her independence. Living with Daisy would be fulfilling all her needs, but Rose wanted to play music loud if she wanted, and to invite friends over or go out without having to ask permission every time.
In five weeks’ time, Rose would begin the arduous task of starting at a new school, meeting new friends, forming bonds, and basically beginning her life again. It was her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt like a veteran at it now. At least she knew this was the last time as she would be starting her final two years at school.

Charlotte Grainger was inspired to write a novel by her primary school teacher. She thought that writing a book would be a challenge and that it was something she could do. When she was 13 years old, she started writing her novel. It is about to be published soon.
Charlotte is a spirited and intelligent teenager. She is also very determined. She has a lot of talent and she is not afraid to work hard to achieve her goals.
Charlotte's novel is a big achievement. It is well-written and engaging. It is also relatable to teenagers. Charlotte is a role model for aspiring writers. She shows that anything is possible if you are willing to work hard and believe in yourself.

Our instructor, Gareth, told us that speed is our friend, not our enemy. We looked down the ski slope and saw David, a skilled freestyle skier, going first. He flew upwards, arms flailing in the air. We held our breath because something was wrong. He hit the ground and flipped head-first into the snow. Gareth said that speed is an unpredictable beast. I had never tried freestyle skiing before, but I thought it would be fun. My parents decided to have a winter holiday at a training centre for freestyle skiing in the US. We practised our moves indoors and then headed outside to try them for real. It was difficult to convince my body to go fast, but I managed to land properly. I felt like I was walking on air. But that was short-lived. On the final run of the day, I forced myself not to reduce speed, became airborne, and landed appropriately in the landing zone.

Imagine you're riding a rollercoaster in an amusement park. You come to a stop and take a deep breath. Then, the rollercoaster starts to move quickly and turns sharply. Your stomach feels like it's in the air. You feel scared and excited at the same time.
Amusement parks are a big industry. To create the thrills and excitement that guests seek, there are teams of engineers and designers working behind the scenes. It's a challenging job to design a rollercoaster. You have to make sure that the ride is safe and exciting. You also have to make sure that the ride is unique and interesting.
The teams behind rollercoasters must work together to create a strong narrative, be it a space adventure or a high-paced chase in the jungle. They must also use their creativity and experience to test and refine the ride.
However, as technology has transformed industry after industry, rollercoaster designers will also have to embrace the latest advances, such as virtual reality. But, according to experts, virtual reality will not replace the physical rollercoaster experience.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has achieved a lot as a choreographer. She creates works for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances from time to time. It's a lot of work to be a choreographer. It's like being in a teaching role and working with young students. They are open to new ideas and willing to try new things.
When Miranda starts working with a new group, she concentrates on the dance steps and the music dictates what she does. Sometimes, it can be frustrating if the dancers don't respond well to the music. But she still has to find solutions.
Miranda doesn't like to be too set in her ways. She feels it's valuable to keep establishing contacts with new people. She also thinks that aiming high is appreciated by audiences.
The conversation turns to the recent documentary on professional ballet dancers and choreographers. The documentary is accurate and shows the hard work and dedication involved in ballet.
Miranda has done a lot of different work. She doesn't like to be labeled or to have a narrow focus. She wants to widen her horizons.
